awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Active Transducers for MEMS Resonators in Integrated Circuit Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
Proposal ECCS 1150071

Project Abstract


RF Micro Electro Mechanical (MEM) resonators, with quality factors (Q)  often exceeding 10,000, have seen several success stories spanning  communication, industrial, and automotive applications. Despite the  maturity of the RF MEMS field, intimate integration with ICs has not  been possible due to complexity and cost of integration and large  disparity between sizes of MEMS devices and integrated circuit (IC)  transistors. The proposed 5-year program exploring multi-GHz MEMS  resonators using electromechanical transduction with IC transistors  will help overcome these obstacles.

Intellectual Merits:
Fundamental innovation in resonator design using this transduction  will enable scaled, monolithically integrated RF MEMS devices with  performance rivaling their off-chip counterparts at previously  unattainable frequencies. Active transduction mechanisms in MEMS  resonators leveraging IC technology for high transducer efficiency  with high-gain, high-fT transistors will be investigated. Actively  transduced resonators will be implemented in a Single Transistor Radio (STaR) and RF front-end filters. These system demonstrations require  innovation in circuit design to harness the benefits of active  transducers in resonators with entirely new topologies.

Broader Impacts:
This research plan is merged cohesively with an education and outreach  objective targeting K-12 and undergraduate students to increase  awareness and understanding of MEMS and Electrical Engineering. Hands-on MEMS demonstrations through local events (e.g. Cambridge  Science Festival and MIT Women's Technology Program) will supplement  web-based demonstrations and tutorials of the MEMS-based radio systems  developed through this program. This work will also serve in the  development of a grad/undergrad MEMS course, introducing fundamentals  of the proposed transducers and MEMS resonators into the curriculum.

por.por_cntn:
As we scale to deep sub-micron (DSM) technology, transistor unity gain frequencies increase, enabling the design of CMOS circuits for RF and mm-wave applications in excess of 100 GHz. However, such high-frequency CMOS transistors have limited gain, resulting in poor output power efficiency. Successful implementation of DSM CMOS in mm-wave applications therefore requires high-Q, low-power components operating at high frequencies.

Another challenge facing DSM circuits is the increasing density of devices, projected to reach 1011devices/cm2. At such densities, clock distribution and the power consumption associated with it necessitate implementation of low-power local clocks with the potential for global synchronization. The NEMS-enhanced electron devices including the Resonant Body Transistor (RBT) under the NSF CAREER program are fundamental building block that addresses both these challenges. We have developed novel CMOS-MEMS RBTs in which a transistor is embedded inside the body of a resonant structure, and efficiently senses high-Q vibrations in the device. This active sensing electromechanically amplifies the desired acoustic signal before the presence of parasitics, enabling high Q, low loss MEMS resonators at higher frequencies than previously accessible.  

Improvements in resonator and oscillator technology operating at multi-GHz frequencies will have a profound impact on a broad range of military, industrial, and consumer applications requiring RF and mm-wave frequency sources, including communications, navigation, radar, and sensors. Low phase noise oscillators employing high-Qelectromechanical resonators can provide high jamming resistance, faster signal acquisition, improved spectrum use, surveillance and security capability, lower error rates, and improved navigation capability, among many other benefits over existing technology.

With the goal of frequency scaling, miniaturization, and power scaling of frequency and timing sources, we are actively pursuing the study and development of high-Q MEMS resonators and oscillators operating in the range of 1-100 GHz. Much headway has been made over the past decade in the development of RF MEMS devices, with successful implementation in transceiver filters (e.g. Avago BAW filters) and timing sources (e.g. SiTime silicon-based oscillators). Nevertheless, several key aspects of RF electromechanical devices have yet to be explored in order to understand and improve device performance beyond the state of the art. To this end, we investigate the following areas using the active MEMS-enhanced electron devices:

Unreleased devices and Integration in CMOS

In the design and fabrication of active MEMS devices, there are clear benefits to integration in standard foundry runs. Direct integration of devices in Front-End of Line (FEOL) CMOS bypasses the complexity of packaging necessary for most MEMS devices without sacrificing performance. Successful FEOL CMOS integration necessitates the design of unreleased RF MEMS devices embedded in the CMOS stack at the transistor level. To ensure high Qand optimal performance of these unreleased devices requires basic study of localized acoustic resonance in 2D and 3D non-homogeneous materials such as the CMOS stack. 

Extension to non-Silicon materials  

The benefits of NEMS-enhanced electron devices are not limited to silicon. We are currently developing active MEMS devices in GaN (though other III-V materials are possible) for high-power, higher-frequency applications beyond the limits of silicon. Unlike silicon-based devices, we can harness the benefits of piezoelectric properties in III-V materials which provide more efficient transduction between the electrical and mechanical domains.  

Through this program, we have realized the first MEMS resonators embedded seamlessly in standard CMOS with no post-processing, and have achieved resonator performance comparable in Quality factor to that of stand-alone MEMS resonators. Techniques have been developed for transducing, guiding, and confining acoustic waves in Si CMOS and GaN MMIC technologies, promising RF building blocks for a range of communication and signal processing applications.
